docs.title: Home
docs.text: Organizer allows to load a bunch of media files, show/play them, and allowing the user to do custom actions on them on the press of a button.

docs.title: Help
docs.text:
Use -h or --help to trigger. Will also trigger if no file is passed to the program.

Will show the program's help then exit.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
$ Organizer-cli --help

Usage: Organizer-cli [options] files...
Organizer

Options:
  -h, --help               Displays help on commandline options.
  -v, --version            Displays version information.
  -p, --profile <profile>  The rule profile file to use.

Arguments:
  files                    The files to organize.

docs.title: Version
docs.text:
Use -v or --version to trigger.

Will show the program's version then exit.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
$ Organizer-cli --version

Organizer 1.2.3

docs.title: Organizing files
docs.text: Simply pass a profile file with -p or --profile and the files you want to be organized, and the rules will be executed as needed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
$ Organizer-cli --profile "rules.json" "image1.jpg" "image2.jpg" "image3.jpg"

Ran rule Test on file image1.jpg
No matching rule for image2.jpg, ignoring
Ran rule Something on file image3.jpg

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
A profile file is a JSON file that contains a single profile as the root object.

A profile is a JSON object with a few options:

  • name: the name of the profile to show in the interface
  • rules: an array or an array of arrays of rules (see Rules)

The first array represents the columns of actions, and the second each row of those columns. When using a single depth of arrays, there will be a single column. This is mainly useful for manual rules.

Example: 

{
    "name": "My profile",
    "rules": [
        {
            // rule 1
        },
        {
            // rule 2
        }
    ]
}

With multiple columns: 

{
    "name": "My profile",
    "rules": [
        [
            {
                // column 1, rule 1
            },
            {
                // column 1, rule 2
            }
        ],
        [
            {
                // column 2, rule 1
            },
            {
                // column 2, rule 2
            }
        ]
    ]
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
A rule is a JSON object with a few options:

  • name: the name of the action that will be displayed on the button
  • shortcut: the assigned keyboard shortcut (ex: H, 3, Ctrl+X, etc.)
  • final: if set to true, triggering this action will also go to the next item (default: false)
  • priority: the priority of this rule when multiple rules match a given file, highest-priority rules will be executed (default: 0)
  • conditions: an array of conditions (see Conditions), if all of them match the actions will be run automatically (default: empty)
  • actions: an array of actions (see Actions) to all be run when executing this rule

Example: 

{
    "name": "Hello",
    "shortcut": "H",
    "conditions": [{
        // ...
    }],
    "actions": [{
        // ...
    }]
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
An action is a JSON object with a few common options:

  • type: the type of the action (such as rename or move)

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Delete the file permanently.

Warning

When designing rules to delete files, it's a good idea to first use the Trash action. You can always change it to delete after you confirmed your rule works as expected.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "delete"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Create a hard link to the file.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• name: what to name the hard link
  • overwrite: set to true to will overwrite any already existing file (default: false)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
  "type": "hardlink",
  "name": "Link to this file"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Move the file to a different directory. The destination can be relative or absolute.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• dest: the destination directory, either absolute or relative to the current browsed directory
  • create: whether to create the destination directory if it doesn't exist (default: true)
  • overwrite: set to true to will overwrite any already existing file (default: false)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "move",
    "dest": "C:\\Users\\Nicolas\\Documents\\Test\\Hello"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Run multiple actions in order. It will immediately stop if one of the actions fail.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • actions: a list of actions (many options such as name, shortcut, or final are unnecessary here)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "multiple",
    "actions": [
        {
            "type": "process",
            // ...
        },
        {
            "type": "move",
            // ...
        }
    ]
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Run a custom command.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• cmd: the binary to call
  • args: the list of arguments to pass to the binary, {var} in either will be replaced by the variables below

docs.title: Available variables
docs.text:
• path: the file absolute path
  • dir: the directory absolute path
  • filename: the full file name (including the extension)
  • basename: the file name without the extension (until the last dot)
  • ext: the file extension (starting from the last dot)
  • /: the native separator of your platform (/ on Windows, \ on UNIX)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "process",
    "cmd": "magick",
    "args": ["{path}", "-resize", "150x150", "{dir}/{basename}_150x150.{ext}"]
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Rename the file. The new name can be in another folder. If it doesn't exist, it will be created.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• from: a regular expression to match the original filename
  • to: what to replace the regular expression match with (use \1, \2... for matched groups)
  • overwrite: set to true to will overwrite any already existing file (default: false)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "rename",
    "from": "!*(.+)",
    "to": "!!!\\1"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Create a Windows shortcut (LNK file) to the file.

Note

This action is Windows-only. On other systems, see the Symbolic link or Hard link actions.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• name: what to name the shortcut (the ".lnk" will automatically be added if not already present)
  • overwrite: set to true to will overwrite any already existing shortcut file (default: false)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
  "type": "shortcut",
  "name": "Shortcut to this file"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Create a symbolic link to the file.

Warning

On Windows, you need elevated permissions to create symbolic links, unless Developer Mode is enabled. Otherwise, you can use the Shortcut or Hard link actions.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• name: what to name the symbolic link
  • overwrite: set to true to will overwrite any already existing file (default: false)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "symlink",
    "name": "Link to this file"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Move the file to the trash.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
{
    "type": "trash"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
A condition is a JSON object with a few common options:

  • data: what data loader to use (such as filename or filesize), see Loader

In addition, each condition can have one Comparator set on it.

Example: 

{
      "data": "filename",
      "glob": "*.jpg; *.png"
}

{
    "data": "created",
    "min": "2017-07-24T15:46:29"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: A comparator is a JSON object that tells the program how to compare the data fetched from the loader.

docs.title: And
docs.text:
Will match if all the comparators contained match.

Example: 

{
    "and": [
        {"regex": "^start_"},
        {"regex": "_end$"},
    ]
}

docs.title: Glob
docs.text:
Will perform a glob match on the data. Multiple patterns can be used with the ";" separator.

Example: 

{
    "glob": "*.jpg; *.png"
}

docs.title: Or
docs.text:
Will match if one of the comparators contained match. Comparators are evaluated in order.

Example: 

{
    "or": [
        {"regex": "^start_"},
        {"regex": "_end$"},
    ]
}

docs.title: Range
docs.text:
Will perform a range check on the data. One or both of min and max can be set. min is inclusive, max is exclusive.

Supports both numbers and dates. Dates are parsed with the ISO 8601 format.

Example: 

{
    "min": 100,
    "max": 200
}

{
    "min": "2017-07-24T15:46:29"
}

docs.title: Regex
docs.text:
Will perform a regex match on the data.

Example: 

{
    "regex": "^start_with_"
}

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: A loader is a string that tells the condition what data to use.

docs.title: Possible values
docs.text:
• created the creation time of the file
  • directory: the canonical absolute path of the directory containing the file
  • filename: the filename
  • filesize: the size of the file on disk, in bytes
  • last_modified: the last modified time of the file
  • path: the canonical absolute path of the file
